when you're composing, i'm assuming you sit at the keyboard and hash it out, but are you hyperscribing that into Finale/or-whatever? or do you flesh it out in your fingers/brain first and notate  it in f or sequencing/composing later?

i never use computer notation programs -- i only do that when i want to use notation in videos. whenever i use notation for writing, i do it on paper, it's much faster. from 2009-2010 i actually wrote everything on paper first, not even using an instrument, i actually did most of it in the library. you can see many of these charts on the site, so you can see the level of detail it includes. it includes exact melody, lyrics, and chords, but not really all the little details of drum parts or aux parts. it will usually have a tempo marking, and sometimes a 'hint' at what the groove should sound like, maybe just referencing another song. but the details of the groove and the little background parts are all worked out during the recording. but the 'road map' (how many bars in each section, how to end it, what the intro is, especially the lengths of things) HAS to be solid before recording. i found that out the hard way. you can't be wondering how it should end when you're recording it. road map has to be set, that's just what i learned. ... Ok, that being said, starting in 2011 i actually learned how to write using a keyboard and voice memo recordings. for a long time i didn't do this because i didn't know how to brainstorm and keep it organized, but i finally figured out how to do it, and wrote like this ever since -- including the massive amount of revisions and updates i made to the existing song catalog during 2012-13. basically there is a master text file, which has a lyric sheet, and every part has a reference audio file that goes with it -- so the text will have the lyric, and then at the end of the stanza or whatever, it would say "see audio 27.mov" and that would be just a desk recording of me demoing how it goes, and perhaps giving other instructions or indications of how to deliver it. sometimes even when the song is done, i might do a paste-together of all these demos, or just do a full run through with a click. occasionally i still might use paper, especially if i have a bridge or something that has really interesting changes, but these days i find it's not even worth it -- does not make for easy access, because it would be buried in a book somewhere and i can't 'search' for the file. Before recording a song, i find it very helpful to make a "studio chart" which is actually just mainly a chord chart, and it also has specific rhythmic indications of when to play certain chords (particularly when certain chords need to be anticipated)

I've been trying to crack down on hand independence on the piano recently. What tips can you give to a semi-beginner to help with hand independence? Thanks <3

i'm not sure. i just kind of do what i need to do. There are a few different "worlds" of playing piano -- one where you play bass with your left hand, chords with your right hand, and sing the melody. there is another world (like if you are in a band) where the bass player plays the bass, and a singer or horn player plays the melody, and just play chords with whatever hand you want. then there is another world like a jazz trio where the bass player plays the bass and you play chords with your left hand and melody with your right hand. and there is another world where you are by yourself and not singing, so you have somehow play all 3 with 2 hands. depending on which world you are in, you would practice different things

hello! since you use your keyboard for drums, do you mix your drums in seperate channels (for snare, kick, hi-hats, etc), or the whole drum machine as one channel?

what i have learned is, it IS smart to mix the kick separate. why? because reverb on the kick is usually a bad idea, but you might want a little rev on the rest. so i actually developed a cool technique to quickly separate it out -- i duplicate the channel, and delete all the kicks in one, and delete all the 'everything else' in the other. that's about it. i could separate it more, but life is short. if i'm doing a song with not much reverb, i might not even bother

When you're writing music (vocal harmonies in particular) do you have the structure mapped out in your head (or on paper) ahead of time before you go about recording each component? Or do you record one track and improvise the harmony over the playback?

doing vocal harmonies to the extent that i do them now is a new thing for me, and i mainly learned it from doing vines every day. but on long songs it's different, because there's so much more territory to cover, and the tendency is to be lazy (because there are so many more miles of song to cover!) -- so here's a new trick i use that allows me to use more harmonies throughout the song without becoming exhaused-- i build it from the lead, and i just pitch shift it all over the place! that's how i write it. so this would be during the recording process, once i have a vocal (or actually the temp vocal) i just make it from the computer -- this encourages me to try crazy things. one of the first times i did this was on "free to do whatever you want to" -- for example, there is one near the end of the bridge (i think on "can't get over my fear") ... i never would have thought to do that if i was like, ready to record, quick what should i sing .  if i'm sitting around and i can just pitch the lead anywhere, i am free to try really crazy stuff. and in the end, whatever i pick is not that hard to sing. so then i just learn it and sing it, and delete the fake one. and now it sounds just as cool, but it's real! so basically, writing it from the computer lets me try out things really quickly, and be really ambitious. then once i get the part, i just learn it and deliver it. On vines, this really doesn't apply, or also on those dense all-chord jingles in history of japan. Those are all being written note for note when i first write it. and it's become a very sensitive thing. a jingle like "it's time for world war 1" i will be sitting at the keyboard meticulously trying different things until the chords are exactly right. And then when i record it, it's pretty simple -- you just sing all the notes of the chords, (taking various other basic considerations). doing vines 7 days a week really accelerated my vocal harmony game, and i'm looking forward to doing much much more of it in the future

Can we get the story behind your song 'do the thing'? I'd really like to hear the thought process behind it, because the lyrics indicate a major change in the singer's behavior. Starting with lines like, "do the thing" and "let me go" but switching to "i don't mind" and "take your time" by the end of it.

this was during a brief period of time when i was actually trying to write in the studio . ...  from the beginning of 2011, all i wanted to do was try more "normal" songs (maybe with verse / cho? maybe with just some simple looping chord changes?) also potentially written in the studio. (i eventually concluded that this is a terrible idea for me). experiments in this phase include "when is it time to come home again" "how am i sposed" and "do the thing" .... basically in all 3 cases, i sort of set up the chord vamp, and then i had a text file open and very spontaneously, the lyrics+melody materialized out of thin air. very basic lyrics, very basic melodies. i just let it follow the path of least resistance. "do the thing" is really like a, 'ok universe, i'm ready to go. please show me the way, take me where i'm supposed to go, i'm ready to see what i need to see now.' ... like a real "surrenduring to the sky" type of thing. honestly, after doing so many complex-weird songs with surprises and weird backflips in 2010, i was ready to try the total opposite. so you get this zoned out, almost dead feeling -- for example the huge gap in the lines in the first verse. also, the "i love you" song was recorded at the same time, and that also subscribes to this ultra-dead zoned out feel. was trying this out, probably mostly as a reaction to some of the madness that ensued in all the 2010 songs (only about 10% of which ever got recorded, by the way). So that's what you have for the verses of 'do the thing' (and by the way, 'do the thing' is not a good title, i kept changing the title and never really found the right title for that song). for the bridge, i sort of reverted to "writing mode," stopped the session, and turned to the writing keyboard / paper, and wrote a bridge -- vastly diff. key, probably thinking in "mccartney" mode. trying to do a really "special" bridge. -- by the way, this is also exactly the same strategy for the "what love is" bridge -- stop the session, turn to the book and write a bridge. I don't really have a good explaination for why the last verse of "do the thing" might feel different, to me it was just common sense to arrive at that place. you can feel a little bit of impatience setting in, like "i'll wait forever if i have to" sort of thing. you know, it's that feeling when you are talking to the sky and you know it's the most important conversation ever, but at the same time, ... you might doubt if it even hears you. The tempo decrease makes it seem even more "dying." i was trying new things, again, breaking away from the ultra-complicated, surprise-based writing, and looking to go outside the box on the simple end instead. Go to the store probably goes even further in that direction.

pretty good, but there are a few mistakes, some more important than others.the sus2's you have at the beginning of the verses are not really strictly obeyed. that's just kind of the way i played it. i would honestly just think "Eb" or "Ab." 2's will sneak in, that would be a players choice. and surely there will be times where you can catch me playing 2's and 3's at the same time. but that's not too important.The next thing i see is at the end of the first stanza, after "never coming back" -- the Ebsus4's you have written -- it should include a 2 also.  however you choose to say that (Ebsus2,4?? sus4,2??who knows). 
the first mistake that actually matters is the Bb7 on connecticut. it's Bb7sus4. actually there's a C note in there too. but NO D. i can firmly say in this song you will not hear Ab and D notes played at the same time. when i use D in the chord, it's just a Bb triad (as you have correctly noted, mostly). 
 so that's a Bb7sus4 or Bb9sus4. (or Fmin7 over Bb if that's not too confusing)
ok moving on, the pickup notes on "oh, i'm" i would definitely specify the bass notes there -- Ab/C, Bb/D.
immediately after that, you said Gm on "canaan", and it's absolutely not Gm, it's Eb/G. on "have a good time" again, it's Bb7sus4 not Bb or Bbsus2. also for what it's worth, the Ab in that line was played as an "add-2" but that is not important, that's just player's choice.  and again, the oscilating chords in the vamp after "good time" includes 2 AND 4.
ok, looks good through the train verse, again the 'sus2's are optional and could go either way.  "Turn" i see you had a question mark. in most of your question mark situations, the magic note here is B. in this case, it is Bb7sus4b9. so again, i stress the fact that there is no D. but there is a B. call it Abmin6 over Bb, call it Bb7sus4b9, whatever. the magic note is B, and there's no D. and there is a Bb (it's in the melody!)
Chorus looks good, just triads, Good job recognizing the Cmin7 (and not Eb) on "blue"!! i always get paranoid that people might not "feel" the 6 bass in those situations when there is no bass. i am glad it came across.  on 'You', the sus4 and major really blend together. if i was playing guitar in the key of E, i would be playing B and letting that high E string ring and blend together. but, close enough.
on "feel, for, you" i have to nitpick. that is Ab, then Eb/G, then Fmin7. beat by beat. at no point is there Ab/G.
last chord before the "countryside" verse, is again Bb7sus4b9. 
the passing chord after "i can find" --  here's how that works -- the bass is playing A. another important note in the chord is B. the way to really execute this properly is to include G, B, and Eb in the chord, and the bass plays A. call it Gaug over A, call it A9b5, call it Ebaug7 over A, whatever (Db note probably wouldn't hurt in there.) but listening to the reality of what happened, it looks like at least one of the keyboards is not adhering to this. you can hear the B note, but it looks like someone is still playing a Bb note on the transition chord. and guess what, it goes by so fast it does not matter. in plenty of "band" situations, the bass player might choose to play this passing A, and they keyboard/guitar players might not know or care, and it still sounds just find because it goes by so fast. 
on "shade", again this is Bb7b9sus4 (or again, Abmin6 over Bb. same thing)
ok, now clearly you have identified something strange happening here on this chord before the bridge (before "i'm gonna go to starbucks"). the first thing i will say is, it is NOT a 4 chord. the 4 chord is where you are going-- this chord would be the equivalent of a Eb7. more specifically, Ebaug7. there is clearly an F note in there too. you might even call it Gaug7. there might not be a Db. Again, one of the keyboards is somehow still playing a Bb note, which might be "illegal" but it doesn't seem to cause any problems. again, the important note is B, and it's basically just Eb+7. the bass for some reason is allowed to riff freely on Ebmaj pentatonic, not caring about the B nat, because for some reason that's just the way it works. it's a transitionary moment, and you can get away with this.
on "starbucks/ukulele" i should comment that the Absus4 is just as legal as it would have been in the "harlem" part, ... it looks like i used it a little less in the 'starbucks' part, although i do hear one of the strings playing that Db note on "play my".
on "Sky", again, this is Bb7sus4. and right before "going" the keys slip in that b9 (B note). on "going" with the melody on G, this chord is really happiest emphasizing that G. seems like Abmaj9 with both C and Bb included. on "feels", AGAIN it's Bb7sus4b9. and again, the vamp oscilation is Ebsus2 and 4 together.
in the last chorus, there are a couple of bass choices that might be worth pointing out in the chords, but you could just blame that on bass player choices. "dream, of, you" once again is Ab, then Eb/G, then Fmin7 (not Ab/G). and again, for "say", it is Bb7sus4b9. 
out vamp is correct. near the end, the bass thinks it's doing like a Bdim to Cmin thing, but the keys don't care. so that is probably not even worth writing down. overall, great job

What is the best way to write lyrics? I'm always struggling with that. It's hard to find rhymes that make sense and mine always sound so cheesy

NEVER CHASE THE RHYME. there is nothing worse than a contrived rhyme. Also, when you chase rhymes, that implies that all your lines will be in sets of 2 that are all the same length. that's just not the way it has to work. Really just open your mind up and take it moment by moment. ask yourself what could you do at each moment that would excite You? you would be surprised how often rhymes show up automatically. but another important thing to remember about "rhymes" in music, --- it really doesn't matter if the consonants rhyme. it really just matters if the vowel rhymes. in music, "fine" and "time" rhyme. no one will ever complain about that. i like to stretch it even more, and sometimes it is actually enjoyable when you break the rhyme. but i will say this again, ...... do not chase the rhyme. the rhymes will always come to you if the time is right. also i should probably mention that i only write lyrics together with the melody. if you are writing only lyrics without a melody, i can understand why you might think you need to search for rhymes. but if put it to a melody, what you will find that the rhymes will want to be in all different places, and the rhymes that you had on paper pre-melody will no longer work. Really what i'm trying to say is, there is absolutely no rules, remain open, and have fun. and never chase rhymes, you will find them coming to you when the time is right

Hey Bill, love your music. I wanted to ask, do you generally prefer to retain a midi/synth-centric sound or is it a matter of necessity at the moment? If you had the resources to use more real instruments would you?Thanks!

music can be made out of anything. i firmly believe this. i was raised with access to midi, and my mom actually showed me how it works when i was about 10. i didn't pick up any kind of guitar until i was at least 15. i did try recording audio (non-midi) somewhere around that time, but there was no more freedom. i couldn't change and adjust parts with anywhere near the same freedom that i could with midi. Sure, you can make great and crazy sounds with audio, but i am not a soundsmith. my strength is in the notes, chords, and thankfully i have now found a way to put words into the mix as well. Recording using audio would be an entirely different animal. an entirely different world. a great world, but completely, completely different. it's about as likely for me to suddenly switch to that as it is for me to suddenly become a professional golfer. also, i think this midi approach has a lot of advantages if you have to work alone. i can fly around between different instruments and make adjustments very quickly, which cushions the damage of the 'alone problem' -- the problem where the first instrument can't hear the later instruments being played and can't react to them. Sure, in audio you can do 'punches' but it still seems limited, and it's just a whole diffent game, plus you probably also need more processing power and i have zero life experience working that way, or thinking that way. i've been doing midi since i was 10. for my situation, the advantages of using midi are insane. The only instrument i use audio for is the vocal, because you have to. and that's more than enough to manage. also with recording audio, you have to actually worry about sound quality, mic quality, all kinds of stuff. and these are things that i have Never worried about. I have been made to feel guilty on multiple occasions for using MIDI, and i used to feel guilty about it then, but then i realized that i have heard plenty of artists use MIDI in amazing ways, so at a certain point i really started to embrace it and never looked back. the thing that i probably envy most in the audio world is stuff like strumming guitars, etc. I do think it is eventually worth it to try to conquer the audio mountain in order to include some of those things, but it would be a huge huge change, and require me to learn to think and function in entirely new ways. also you would now have to worry about guitar quality!! worry about the strings, worry about intonation, worry about amps maybe, worry about miking, on and on, more and more issues that i have never even touched. not to mention another even bigger issue: working with other people. using audio would require me to go back to the stone age in many, many, many ways. and i would do it immediately if i could live forever. perhaps i would also become a molecular biologist</exclude>

How long did alphabet shuffle take, and what was its backstory?

looks like i created the music proj file june 4, and the final video was done june 14. this doesn't really include the writing. although the last line of the bridge (alright, etc) was written this month. Original idea is from early 2012. it's a floater, it's been kicking around in the system for a while, and got finished little bits at a time. 10.18.13 looks like i solidified the chord specifics of the "tags" (the extra wxyz's, etc) and also started the bridge (up until 'i'm alive'). then last month when i was trying to find a path back into songs (and start actually choosing songs for once instead of randomizing them) this one was the only sensible starting point. and i finished the bridge and just settled for basic "AABA" form, and figured if anyone complains there's no jokes, oh well. how did you got inspired for making the song and vid of new canaan? i really love it

was in penn station one time and i was just like 'damn, there's trains here that go to the entire world, i just pick somewhere and see what's there. even if it's nothing, i don't care, i want to go.'  so 4 different times that month (may 2009) i took a songbook and went to a random place, and wrote a song on the way. new canaan got some very very small edits (mainly in the last verse) in 2012. got recorded in 2014 on the wednesday song schedule. then it came up for a tuesday music video a few months later, and being almost 3 minutes, it was extremely ambitious to fit in to the schedule... basically means i had to do the video in about 1 day, which is why it is Extremely low budget...  just did like 1 full length vocal take, 1 drum take, maybe did a couple specific bass fills.... and there's hardly any graphics... the occasional train or map just barely makes it interesting enough.ultimately i'm glad it got recorded, it was very high on my most-wanted list (mainly because of that license plate line, honestly) for many years

what's "the road" about? (which road, specifically?)

more of a writing experiment. written in early 2012. hadn't written anything in a long time, and 2011 was more about chasing 'normal' writing techniques, and writing using text and recorders, using verse-chorus form, etc... But at this point i was getting restless and missed the days when i used to write songs on paper, beginning to end, in the library. (string-writing, or chain-writing ... train-writing .. whatever you want to call it). So i just hit the page, and 'the road' came out. i just went wherever i wanted to go, and the whole thing stays about equal melodic and harmonic density, yet without any real repeating patterns of any kind. changes keys all over the place. a fun time to get really frisky with key changes. might be inspired by some of the crazier donald fagan writing. the lyrics just came out automatically.  everything changes after the "now i know" part .... and i'm not sure exactly what that means. in a song like this about "searching" it might seem surprising to eventually "find" the thing! but it just happened. and the mood sounds a bit strange after that, especially converging on the last line (which i didn't know was going to be the title until the end) .... almost feels like i'm saying everything's fine and i found my way, but it's obvious listening to the harmonic mood that something's not totally cool.

kind of curious, how was the transition to long-form content in history of japan? was there anything about the process that was noticeably different/unique from making vines and songs? and i'm guessing it was also different starting from researched work on a random topic and trying to make it "your own" versus being inspired by events in your life (which seems to be how you usually get ideas)- did that trip you up any?

Everything is different when you increase the length of the project. even things you wouldn't expect to be different. and going from 7 seconds to 9 minutes is a huge difference. i already noticed how different things were when i made some 2 and 3 minute music videos earlier that year. every possible element of the project becomes very different, and new challenges are raised. one unexpected example is, processing power. when i was doing history of japan, by about 3 minutes in, the computer slowed down to the point where i couldn't do anything. and there were actually glitches starting to occur on the render!! so ultimately what i had to do was split the project up into chapters, no longer than about 1 minute. and very carefully allign them so that i could seamlessly export one and import it into the next sequence. i did the same thing when doing score. this is just one example of the many things that are unexpectedly different when the project size changes

what was the inspiration for "im crazy / it's raining"?

written in early 2012, i sort of was exhaused from all the years gone by of trying to write really crazy stuff, and then trying to write really normal stuff (2011) and just in general so much time had gone by trying to write in different ways, trying to improvise in different ways, writing in text (which goes back even further) .... just feeling like i had tried everything and yet i still hadn't made any of it public yet. crazy/raining sort of was like that peaceful yet kind of hopeless feeling of  "well, i think i've tried absolutely everything, i've tried more things, i've tried less things, i've tried not trying things, i've tried trying too many things, ..... and i still haven't really put it together. and i have no energy left. where am i now?" there is this feeling of being totally exhausted from trying everything, and yet, the steady "rain" still falls -- the steady rain of you still wanting to do all the things you want to do. the steady feeling that you STILL want to express yourself in crazy and/or meaningful ways. the fact that even if you feel totally drained and dead, the rain still falls. that's sort of why the song sounds very plain and doesn't really have any creative melody tricks, or any strange lyrics, .... it's just like rain. i've always debated whether to record it, because i wasn't sure if it was too boring. but it came up on a randomized selection in 2015, and i reluctantly gave it a shot

Written songs keep piling up, and I'm never satisfied with what I have already recorded. Mixing issues, mostly: bass too loud, sibilance, etc etc. To relieve stress, more songwriting takes place, and at the same time, no new recording takes places because it feels "wrong" to move on until those old recordings are "OK". Somtimes, I get on a roll of "just doing it" (like what u said about demon-killing songs), and it feels so, so great! The experience stacks up, and slowly things start feeling smoother, it flows. But at some point I will always look back at the first recordings and think, "that was a good song, but it's recorded terribly. Maybe I should go back..." and that halts the whole flow. I guess there's no real answer to this situation, but I'm wondering if, besides the demon-killing, did you set yourself any "limits" too? Like, "once a song is recorded, that's it"? It takes so much willpower to do, but I guess sometimes songs n eed to b e used as fuel to kindle the fire of future songs. Or something. It's hard!!!

What's the history of "i can play"? (I can't get this song out of my head.)

it was originally written in 2 different 2010 library sessions. (ref: i-can-play.pdf">here is the chart for the original version. as you can see there are 2 dates on the top, i think the split point is somewhere at the end of the second chorus, that's where i stopped and picked up again in the second session. that was in 2010, and it looks like all the lyrics and sections and pretty much the whole song was there. in 2013, i looked at it again, and made an update. <a href="i-can-play-2013-update.pdf)here is the 2013 update it looks like it was transposed, and the chords are clarified and slightly adjusted throughout. but the biggest change is the second chorus -- looks like the second chorus was totally re-written, and now goes on a harmonic adventure through key changes. and the end vamp is re-worked. the song was recorded in 2014 for a wednesday song release, and these charts are obeyed almost exactly. on a tight weekly/daily schedule, as with most of the releases in 2014, any song over 30 seconds is under severe time constraints in the production process, so as a result this recording is very hasty, and i hardly had time to mix the vocal at all, so some of the lines are too loud, and the whole thing is pretty hasty

when do you think your next history video will be done?

i am about 30 to 45 seconds into the writing. i really like the direction that it is going. i am using the same strategy as i did for history of japan, which is "say as much as you need to say to sufficiently explain the topic FAST and efficiently, but make it as long as you need." when the writing is done, i will do a timed read through and then i will know how long it is. i am guessing it will be anywhere between 5 and 10 minutes. (if i can say everything i want to say in 3, that would be fine too. if it takes 15, ...... i guess that's fine too.) japan clocked in at exactly 9 minutes on the first timed run through. i am also working on this video every day, every available hour (just like the last one.) The main difference between this time and last time is this: during the 14 weeks that it took to make history of japan, i was also writing and creating short videos for vine Every Single Day for about the first 2/3 of the time i was working on history of japan. so that would be maybe about half the work time each day devoted to vine, and NOT the history video. Now i am not doing that. so that would be a significant reason why this video might get done faster. Also, after making history of japan, i have refined some of my techniques a bit more, and might be able to work faster.  However, the scope of this topic is a bit different, which might present some unforseen challenges. There is also a small chance that I may decide to make a short video just to have Something to release during the long haul (although i might NOT do that, because that will only directly delay the release of the long video.) The good news is, i have a 1 minute song and music video already completed which i am waiting to upload. i am saving it for when i am deep in the depths of production on this long video, so i have something to release. i hope that answers your question

I'm not really that good at writing music but I like to make it anyway. I've been using GarageBand for instrumentals and Notes for lyrics. I don't think it'll amount to anything and I sometimes wonder if I took music theory classes, which I don't want to take, whether I would get better and whether it would be worth it. Basically what it boils down to is "do I want to waste my time doing something that will help in the long run but that I really don't want to do and that I don't need or do I want to teach myself and get better agonizingly slowly but have a lot more fun doing it"

news flash.... the fact that you "don't want" to learn "music theory" is a sneak preview that you are not going to learn it if you expect someone else to teach it to you. that's just the nature of "music theory" and/or ... the nature of learning in general, i think! you can't just go to the doctor and get a 'shot' of 'music theory' and know it. besides ..... it doesn't really exist!! the way "music" "theory" (if there is such a thing) works is .... it's really just how you choose to make sense of the musical world you live in.  Every "music theory" class really is just an extrapolation of what seems to be the principles among a CERTAIN SET of music that was popular during a certain time period.  If you go to a classical school, they will teach you things that relate to what was popular in europe several centuries ago. if you go to berklee, they will probably teach you a lot about what was popular in the 1940s. there could be a class based on only the last 20 years of music, and it would be different still. there is really only a small amount of stuff that is really actually established and unchanging. like note names -- europe named the notes with letters a few centuries ago, and it really stuck. the entire world uses those notes. do you know them? (A, Bb, B, C, etc)
i've known many many musicians in my life, and also many people who were in music school, and anyone who really gets how music works did not learn it from a class. they may have been in a class, but what is really going to give you the knowledge is going to come from you. and it will need to happen in your own way. in other words, i have absolutely never met anyone that had music theory entirely 'bestowed' or given to them from only an outside source. i've said this many times, but really the best way to go about it is from the context of music you know and like. Learn that music! learn how to play it. learn how to play those melodies. learn how to play those chords. (and don't expect a chord to always have 3 notes or always be next to each other!) Learn the music you already know. you Will find principles, and you will get to know them very well. THEN, later on, perhaps you will stumble upon a music textbook or something, and 'take a glance' inside, ... and you will probably start to find things that you are familiar with, and maybe you will learn a name or 2.  But really that's just learning the names of something you already knew. That won't actually make you 'better,' it only helps in the sense that it helps you communicate with other musicians in a working situation. But that only goes so far, because the majority of musicians (including professionals) really don't know 'official music theory' that deeply, regardless of how experienced they may be. Again, there really is no 'official music theory' beyond a couple very small things -- note names ...  and key signatures i guess. Everything else will be stylistically catered to the way music might have been played at a certain time in history. so that is why you are best off approaching it from exactly the standpoint that you are used to. i hope that answers your question

So hopefully this question isn't too personal for your tastes - and if it is, I hope you choose to answer it by means other than this page - because honestly, I am baffled by you. Have you already made your full length songs? When will you post them?

during the last 5, no fuck it, 7 years, i have been writing them in massive, massive quantities. i started recording a few of them in 2009 and continued to reacord many throughout 2010. but i also kept writing even more. then i wrote more. then i recorded a few in 2011, and stlil wrote more. some of them were fragments. in 2012 i started organizing the fragments and writing on all of them, and finishing many of them. i wrote constantly with no recording for the next couple years. in 2014 i started making short videos regularly, and recording a song (picked from the archive) once a week. but the longer ones couldn't really get done that often because i was on such a tight schedule. the success i've had with videos has gotten in the way of having time to do songs. research videos also became important to me, so i had to tackle that. now that that door is at least opened, i think it's time to think about songs. to clarify, every song i've ever recorded has been released (except for maybe 1 or 2 which came out really bad). there are many many many many more written, and many more partially written, and i feel like my songwriting is in a better place now than ever before, after all the practice i got in 2012/13, as well as all the practice i got doing all those jingle vines. i probably over answered your question. Trust me, if i had stuff recorded, i would post it. the defining problem of my life is that i can't record nearly as fast as i can write
Is there coming a new big video out soon like the history of japan? or nah?

i am heavily divided right now. history and/or research videos is enormously important, and i want to do as many as possible, but also releasing a huge amount of songs (including ones in the 2 or 3 minute range) is something i have been working toward for most of my life. (i spent all of 2012 and 2013 writing!) so if i don't figure that out soon, my life will explode. But i also don't want to drop the research/history thing, because it is also very important to me, and i know many many people are also eagerly awaiting it. i am trying to figure out how to not fragment my career. yesterday i actually started writing a research/history video, and i am very confident in where it's going, but i am also gravely aware that if i don't jump seriously into recording songs in large quantities, i may die. that being said, i have a 1 minute song all set with video that will be coming out next week, which might help kick things off. i'm really not sure if i'm going to push full speed ahead with this history video now, or try to push forward with songs, or whatever. reaching this decision is exactly what i will be doing for the next couple days. it is very precarious

i know you've mentioned a few times here that we shouldn't change for anyone or do anything just because someone else wants us to, but you said that in early 2015 you were showing your face in videos quite often then stopped because people didn't like it. Why is that?

that actually wasn't the reason i stopped. i actually didn't stop ..... let me see if i can explain this .... on the original 5-day (ref: http://billwurtz.com/schedule.png"schedule, i was basically in the video once a week. after taking a break, i came back to a 2 day schedule, which specifically had me appearing once a week (only 2 videos per week.) all those videos got uploaded to vine in a condensed period of time (1 video per day) so when videos from the 2 day schedule went up to vine, that would mean i was appearing every 2 days on vine. and still if you look at the youtube stream, it is every other video. those videos were coming out monday and thursday. so it's still once a week. after the <a href="http://www.billwurtz.com/vine-content-horizon.jpg)vine content horizon, i had to start actually making 7 days a week to maintain the 7 day schedule on vine, and i decided to preserve the monday/thursday formats, and just surround them with jingles. thursday's format shifted to band videos instead of spoken 1-liners, but it was still a chance for me to be in the video. still once a week. throughout the following months, that mostly stayed the same. i may have missed a couple thursdays, and also tried to make up for it. but i continued to appear in them roughly once a week, all the way through the majority of the time working on history of japan, all the way up until the point when i finally quit doing vines in order to finish history of japan. then history of japan came out, and i decided to build a journal page and edit 6 years worth of journals, and also build improv pages and do improv edits. (which by the way, i do appear in some of). so overall i don't think there is a very convincing argument that i stopped. although it is true that during the time when the 2 day schedule was going up to vine, there were people who indicated that they were tired of seeing me every other day. but there was nothing i could do about it, because i was uploading all the videos in order. i do think it is important to appear in videos reasonably often, because i don't want it to be shocking when i do

you used to decide what to work on according to length, then with a randomizer, and it seems now you're trying to pretty evenly distribute music/short stuff/long videos over time. are you using any sort of system now to decide what to work on?

i am now "writing the queue" in a more human way than ever before, and i think that is a breakthrough for me. the short videos (including 'what is love') were all newly written as i made the queue (not selected from the archive). i have added some songs to the queue which i HAVE picked randomly, but I'm doing it differently than before -- now I'm actually randomizing from the entire list of songs including ones that are not 100% done (writing), where as before i would only pick from the completed list, and as a result the ones selected were always very old, because the newer ones are usually unfinished (writing). but now i have actually made a list that includes all the partially written ones (including ones that are just a title, or just one line, or even just an idea.) and whatever gets picked, i have to write it to completion. as a result, the finished items will include more newer and stronger writing. So far 3 song picks have been made, the first one was about 50% done, the second one was 100% done but i changed part of it, and the third one was really just a short (very traditional) chord form with barely a dummy melody, and i finished and wrote the whole thing. The entire current queue of items was made/selected/written between 5/20 and 5/26, and it has 11 items, starting with "thinkin bout doing some content." after those 11 items, there is a history video which is currently only a title. after picking that title, i decided to start production on the videos. The list may change, and i am trying very hard to resist the hammering from the public to "just do another history video" and i am trying very hard to remember that no one was asking for a history video before i did it (they wanted vines forever), and that following through in my own way is what made that what it was, and i am trying to remember to continue operating like that.

just wondering what's the chord change at the end of your 'what is love?' video? (i.e. the 'hell yeah' one)

key is Bb, and i will tell you the notes.  on "hell," bass is F, melody is C. important harmony notes are Eb and Gb, less important is Bb (NOT A, A WOULD RUIN THIS).  and "yeah" is just Bb maj triad (Bb, D, F).  to express it in terms of chord symbols, you might accurately say F7sus4b9, or Ebmin6 over F, or Cdim (or half dim, NOT dim7) over F. all would be equally accurate. the important note that makes the magic happen is the Gb, and it is the same note that makes 4min chords happen. i hope that answers your question

can you reveal, or have you already, which song(s) made no sense that you wrote outside the brooklyn museum?

let me see if i can explain this clearly... 9.17.10 was the actual writing session, actually sitting outside the brooklyn museum, with a binder (with paper). i was writing really short stupid tunes. the first one was called '(ref: run.jpg"run.' the second one was called '<a href="write-me-another.jpg)write me another.' 'write me another' got recorded a month later, along with many others. 'run' never got recorded. 
much later, in 2013 during a year-long writing sweep, both of those songs came up for evaluation/re-write/delete consideration. 'run' actually got split into 2 songs -- i basically separated the 'run' part and called that its own song (run), and then i took the 'looking glass' part and added a new ending, ('elf') which actually carries on the original narrative and explains more details about the 2010 writing session (fine morning in brooklyn, etc etc). 'write me another' also got a 2013 evaluation (which was unusual for already recorded songs, but for some reason i thought it was worth looking at) and one of the possible endings i was looking at was "i'm gonna plan my day"... but that line ended up being its own thing. another option was 'i just wrote a song and it made no sense, i'm here outside the brooklyn museum, etc etc" and that is the one i ended up going with. so, again, this actually explains more details about the original situation, despite the fact that that part was actually written years later. later still, in 2014, when i was doing 4 videos a week and 1 song every wednesday, the new version of "just wrote a song (now called brooklyn museum)" got recorded. so as a result, there are 2 recordings that start with the exact same line (i just wrote a song) one recorded in 2010 and one recorded in 2014. the 'i'm gonna plan my day' bit also got picked for a wednesday during 2014. also, the 'elf' bit  got picked. it's important to remember that during 2014, i had to pick short songs way too often, because there just wasn't enough time to do anything of length, and anything short that was any good got picked earlier in the year, so by september (or whenever it was) i was only left with the worst ones (like these ones, or macys, or whatever). basically i'm apologizing for this crap. it was all written way before i knew what i was doing (2010), and through a series of circumstances ended up being recorded, hastily. i hope that makes sense

Maybe a lame question (cause music can speak for itself) but is their any story behind "you're free to do whatever you want to"? I know at the end of the video it appears you wrote the song about 6 years ago.

i had just moved into a church. also had just broken up with my girlfriend. i had a lot of free time, and started writing a lot. i was experimenting with a writing technique which i was calling "murder your demon" which is where you deliberately say complete garbage at the top of the song for 4 bars (or anywhere in the song), and try to be as terrible as possible and get it all out of your system. if you actually aim straight at hell on purpose, it has interesting effects on what comes next. songs like fever (is what makes you sick), blind (to no avail), feel okay, 2010, i like, free to (do whatever you want to), tape deck, barf on me, the summertime, and song 41 were all written during that month (august 2010). i recorded some of them during the following weeks/months, and some of them remained unrecorded until years later. some still unrecorded (not mentioned).
